relation: Howard is known for it's numerous parties around the campus and is known for both it's high end parties as well as it's house parties. Those who don't like to party can also go about the city to U Street, catch the Metro to Chinatown or catch the bus to Georgetown.

The food options around campus are improving, but they are still limited in number and quality on campus. Currently, the CafÃ?Â© of the Caf is the central hub of dining activity. It is used mainly by freshman students and those who have a meal plan. Upperclassmen typically go the Punchout which is opposite of the Caf in the Blackburn Center. The Punchout is a place where there are fast food options for students which are great for those with tight schedules and need to grab a bite to eat. There is a restaurant in the upper level of the Blackburn center in addition to a coffee stand in the administration building.

While Howard's dorms are not entirely modern or state of the art. There is a culture that Howard dorms create by themselves. In each dorm there is a brother or sisterhood created, particularly in the freshman dorms such as Drew, The Tubman Quad, The Annex, and Carver. These dorms usually compete in a competition annually called ResFest which materializes the fun rivalries between the dorms and allows a nice distraction from the academic push during the latter half of the academic year.

Howard is an institution where academic programs are rigorous based on the major. Science, business, and engineering, or mathematics majors usually tend to have the most difficult classes while those in Fine Arts are evaluated comprehensively. Health majors also share the burden of science majors in certain classes as well.

New students should come with an expectation to work hard in and out of the classroom. Success here is not dependent solely on your GPA, but how you engage the opportunities that are abundant here. You should work hard to make sure that you prepare yourself for the world that the university introduces yourself to. Branch out and do not limit yourself to the bounds of the main campus, it will be highly rewarding if you do this as Washington D.C is rich in opportunities by itself.

Howard University is an institution where real life meets an academic experience. For you to completely gain the experience you must arrive with an open mind along with a willingness to learn. The social scene also great allowing many networking opportunities that are not offered elsewhere.

Tips for prospective students Don't party too hard during your first semester. I know several people who will not be able to complete their education at Howard because they were the ones getting ready every Thursday/Friday/Saturday night for the club instead of studying. Also be aware of your surroundings. Travel in large groups during the night and use the shuttles as much as possible so you won't have to worry about walking back to the dorms all the way from the metro. When you're about to buy books for classes, ask upperclassmen and look around campus for flyers of people selling their books for cheaper than the bookstore prices. Join clubs and community service organizations to build up your experience for those future internships and jobs. Stay focused on your grades.
